climbs.name: Najjar's Rift
climbs.fa: (first lead or solo unknown) TR Brian Najjar 2008

content.description:
Some thoughtful moves higher up. 

  Straight up the gully. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is unknown (because most people either Top-Rope it or solo it). 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Alexander Hamilton sector.
content.location:
Gully between overhanging ridge with a crack on its right, and an overhanging wall with an irregular wide crack. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
It's all about the crux sequence, and what a crux it is -- would be like indoors except that one key hold is rather abrasive. 

  Up the lift side to under the big overhang. Hand traverse right (? feet ?). Then up left-trending wide crack to top. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate. 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Alexander Hamilton sector.
content.location:
Big overhang just around the corner right from the gully. Rock has unusual horizontal many little overhangs like two inches high each. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Thoughtful outdoor sequence in mid-lower part, then a thoughtful crux finish. 

  Up the crack to a wide section, overcome that and up to bulge at top. Finish up over around its right side onto top of ridge. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate. 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Alexander Hamilton sector.
content.location:
Obvious overhanging vertical crack at left side of overhanging ridge which is left of the gully. The main wall to its left side is higher than the top of the ridge. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Sustained thoughtful with a variety of techniques, including a tricky exit. 

  Straight up the crack from bottom to top.   Consider starting from standing on top of rock to left of crack -- the route is sufficiently tough even with that advantage). 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is unknown (? though there's a vague rumor that it's been led ?) 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Alexander Hamilton sector.
content.location:
Vertical crack by left end of wide slab face (with vertical bottom) about fifteen feet right past big overhang from gully. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Not often that we find an outdoor arete with positive holds and multiple overhanging bulges (with underclings?) 

  Up the ridge, avoiding the easier climbing lower on its right side. But then the final bulge might need some moves to the right. 

  Variation (easier and less exciting but still worthwhile): Use the face on the right side of the ridge, but not the gully. 

  name? see Broadway musical of the teens. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate. 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Alexander Hamilton sector.
content.location:
The ridge just right of the obvious vertical crack and just left of the gully. The top of the ridge is overhanging, but lower than the main wall on the left side of the crack. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Outdoorsy (awkward?) low sequence leads to fun (indoorsy?) upper sequence. 

  Up overhanging blocks below right from crack to wide ledge. Move left to crack, and up that to the top. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible, behind a large tree).
content.protection:
Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate. 

  For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Alexander Hamilton sector.
content.location:
Below irregular wide crack starting about 8-10 feet up in wall just right of the gully. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Overhanging except for the central gully.   About 25 feet tall. Facing SW. 

  Top-Rope: One way to get access to set up an anchor using trees or rocks above top of this cliff is to walk about 100 feet right and scramble up. Another way is to climb up the central gully (5th class). 

warning: The rock around this sector has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber.
